feed.title: NewsTracker: mexico
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Subterranean river discovered under Mexico's Mayan ruins
entry.summary:
Experts from Mexico's National Autonomous University say they found a subterranean cavity about 20 metres (yards) deep below the pyramid of Kukulkan, also known as El Castillo.

Such underground rivers often connect the open "cenotes," or sinkhole lakes, that dot Mexico's Yucatan peninsula.

entry.title: Subterranean river discovered beneath Mexico's Chichen Itza ruins
entry.summary: Experts have discovered that the main pyramid at Mexico's Mayan ruins of Chichen Itza was at least partially built atop a subterranean river.

entry.title: 2 plead guilty to smuggling heroin from Mexico by drone
entry.summary: It was the first drug seizure involving a drone along California's border with Mexico, said Lauren Mack, spokeswoman for U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement in San Diego.

entry.title: The Latest: EPA chief visits New Mexico to see spill fallout
Reputed gang leader, reporter, 4 others killed in Mexico
entry.summary: MEXICO CITY (AP) " Five gunmen burst into a bar early Thursday and killed a reputed drug gang boss, a reporter and four other people in Mexico's Gulf coast state of Veracruz, authorities said.

entry.title: The Latest: EPA head to visit New Mexico to address spill
entry.summary:
The pollution has passed through parts of Colorado, New Mexico, Utah and the Navajo Nation.

The head of the Environmental Protection Agency plans to visit Colorado and New Mexico sometime Wednesday to see the impact of a 3 million gallon mine waste spill triggered during an agency-led cleanup.

entry.title: The Latest: EPA head to visit New Mexico to address spill
entry.summary:
A 100-mile-long plume has since traveled for hundreds of miles, through parts of Colorado, New Mexico and Utah on the way to Lake Powell, a key source of water for the Southwest.

The head of the Environmental Protection Agency says she will visit Farmington, New Mexico, downstream from where millions of gallons of mine waste spilled into a southwest Colorado river.

entry.title: 2 plead guilty in California to smuggling nearly 30 pounds of heroin from Mexico by drone
entry.summary:
-- Two California men pleaded guilty to using drones to smuggle nearly 30 pounds (13.61 kilograms) of heroin from Mexico to the United States, authorities said Wednesday.

Elias took over control of the drone from an operator in Mexico after the aircraft crossed the border, Mack said.

entry.title: Ford shifts truck production from Mexico to Ohio
Mexico to question governor over journalist's killing
entry.summary: Javier Duarte, Veracruz governor, has told local media that he has no knowledge of the incident, which occurred on July 31 in a Mexico City apartment where four women were also slain.

entry.title: Mexico governor to be questioned over killing of photojournalist
entry.summary:
The governor of the Mexican state of Veracruz, Javier Duarte, will be questioned over the recent murder of five people in the country's capital, including a photojournalist, the mayor of Mexico City said on Monday.

"I have commented to him (Governor Duarte) that we are required to take a statement directly from the governor," Mexico City mayor Miguel Angel Mancera told reporters on Monday.

In a rare move for Mexico, a group of investigators from the city prosecutor's office will travel to Veracruz on Tuesday to take a statement from Duarte.

entry.title: The Latest: New Mexico calls out feds over mine spill
entry.summary:
People are getting their well water tested in northwestern New Mexico after a plume of contaminated water spilled from a Colorado mine into the Animas River.

Farms along the Animas and San Juan river valleys in New Mexico have no water to irrigate their crops after a massive spill from a closed Colorado mine.

The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has yet to say if the metals, which include lead and arsenic, pose a threat to human health, frustrating residents and state and local officials in Colorado and downstream in New Mexico and Utah.

entry.title: The Latest: New Mexico Calls out Feds Over Mine Spill
The Latest: New Mexico calls out feds over mine spill
entry.summary:
The head of the New Mexico Environment Department is calling out federal officials for not quickly notifying the state of a toxic wastewater spill from an abandoned Colorado mine.

The New Mexico Environment Department partnered with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency to begin testing the water Monday.

entry.title: Activist in search for missing students killed in Mexico
entry.summary: Miguel Angel Jimenez, a political activist who played a prominent early role in the search for 43 students and other missing people in southern Mexico, was slain over the weekend, an associate said Monday.

entry.title: Activist in search for missing students killed in Mexico
entry.summary: In July, Mexico's attorney general's office confirmed that at least 60 clandestine graves with 129 bodies have been found so far on the outskirts of Iguala.

entry.title: Activist in search for missing students killed in Mexico
Tainted wastewater that spilled from Colorado mine flows toward New Mexico, Utah
entry.summary: New Mexico officials were angry they were not told of the spill until Thursday, nearly a day after it occurred.

entry.title: Wastewater from Colorado mine flows toward New Mexico, Utah
entry.summary:
DENVER (AP) - An eerie yellow sludge that poured out of a shuttered gold mine and into a southwestern Colorado river was inching its way downstream toward New Mexico and Utah.

Local officials declared stretches of the river off-limits in Colorado and New Mexico.

entry.title: Wastewater from Colorado mine flows toward New Mexico, Utah
entry.summary: Water samples were also tested in New Mexico, but no results had been released.

entry.title: New Mexico blasts EPA for late notice on Colorado mine spill
entry.summary:
Officials in New Mexico are blasting the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency for not informing them soon enough about a plume of mustard-colored muck floating downstream from a Colorado mine.

New Mexico's environment secretary, Ryan Flynn, said Friday that the EPA downplayed the danger the contamination posed to wildlife, saying that potential harm can't be known until the contents of the wastewater and their concentrations are known.

entry.title: New Mexico blasts EPA for late notice on Colorado mine spill
Sludge from Colorado mine spill heads down river to New Mexico, towns take precautions
entry.summary:
The creek runs into the Animas, which then flows into the San Juan River in New Mexico and joins the Colorado River in Utah.

As the plume headed toward New Mexico, that state's governor said the EPA waited too long to tell her about the problem.

Gov. Susana Martinez is disturbed by the lack of information provided by the agency to New Mexico's environmental agencies, said Chris Sanchez, a spokesman for the governor.

In Farmington, New Mexico, city officials shut down water-supply intake pumps to avoid contamination and advised citizens to stay out of the river until the discoloration has passed.

entry.title: Prosecutor: Mexican suspect was at apartment where 5 slain
entry.summary:
In this April 28, 2015 photo, Mexican photojournalist Ruben Espinosa places a plaque to rename a plaza after slain journalist Regina Martinez in the city of Xalapa, in Mexico's Gulf state of Veracruz.

Three years ago Martinez was killed and now on August 1, Espinosa himself was tortured and killed along with four other people inside an apartment building in Mexico City, the city where he had sought refuge after being threatened in the state of Veracruz.

entry.title: Mexico City prosecutor says suspect acknowledges being at apartment where 5 slain
entry.summary: MEXICO CITY - A man suspected in the killings of a Mexican photojournalist and four women has acknowledged being in the apartment where the slayings occurred, Mexico City's top prosecutor said Thursday.

entry.title: News24.com | Mexico prosecutor: Video has suspects in journalist killing
entry.summary: Mexico City Prosecutor Rodolfo Rios Garza said the three men are the prime suspects in the killing of journalist Ruben Espinosa, cultural promoter Nadia Vera and three other women, including a domestic employee.

entry.title: Mexico City mayor vows full probe of journalist slaying
entry.summary:
The family of murdered photojournalist Ruben Espinosa are overcome with grief during his funeral service in Mexico City, Monday, Aug. 3, 2015.

Mexico City's mayor said Monday that no expense will be spared and no line of investigation ignored in the hunt for the killers of four women and a photojournalist, who had fled the state where he worked fearing for his safety.

The United Nations High Commission on Human Rights condemned the killings, saying that the bodies had signs of torture and sexual violence and that the climate of impunity "is one of the obstacles to practicing freedom of expression in Mexico."

The casket of murdered photojournalist Ruben Espinosa is surrounded by his photo, flowers and a mural inside a funeral home before his wake begins in Mexico City, Monday, Aug. 3, 2015.

Friends said Espinosa had fled Xalapa, the capital of Veracruz, to Mexico City in June after saying that unknown people were following him, taking his photograph and harassing him outside his home.

entry.title: New Mexico Gov. Martinez: 'Coward' set off 2 church blasts
entry.summary: New Mexico Gov. Susana Martinez is promising that the "coward" who set off explosions outside two Las Cruces churches will be caught.

entry.title: Free speech advocates fear more impunity in latest Mexico journalist killing
entry.summary:
"The level of impunity is what allowed this to happen," said a journalist in Mexico City who also had to flee Veracruz.

"Displaced journalists used to come to Mexico City as an island of protection. Now there is no place to go, no place to run."

entry.title: Advocates fear more impunity in Mexico photographer killing
entry.summary: Espinosa, 31, who worked for the investigative magazine Proceso and other media was found murdered along with 4 women, in an apartment in a middle-class neighborhood of Mexico City, where he had fled because of harassment in the state he covered.

entry.title: Gov?t reaction criticized in case of Mexico slain journalist
entry.summary:
Journalists and activists hold up cut-out images of slain photojournalist Ruben Espinosa during a protest at Mexico City's Angel of the Independence monument, Sunday.

A person holds up a black Mexican "mourning" flag and flowers during a protest over the murder of photojournalist Ruben Espinosa at Mexico City's Angel of the Independence monument, Sunday.

Rios never acknowledged that Espinosa was seeking refuge in Mexico City, saying he came to the capital for "professional opportunities."

entry.title: Journalist slain in Mexico City had signs of torture
entry.summary: A photographer for the Mexican investigative magazine Proceso, who had fled his home state after being harassed, was among five people found slain early Saturday in an apartment in Mexico City, according to the magazine.

entry.title: Journalist slain in Mexico City had signs of torture
entry.summary:
Espinosa was found slain, along with four other people early Saturday in an apartment in Mexico City, according to the magazine.

Journalists protest the murder of photojournalist Ruben Espinosa Becerril as they hold printouts of his photo, in Mexico City, Sunday, Aug. 2, 2015.

entry.title: Explosions shock congregants at 2 New Mexico churches
entry.summary: Several agencies including the FBI, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives and New Mexico State Police are assisting with the investigation.

entry.title: Explosions shock congregants at 2 New Mexico churches
entry.summary: LAS CRUCES, N.M. (AP) - A pair of small explosions just 20 minutes and a few miles apart shocked congregants Sunday morning at two churches in southern New Mexico.

entry.title: Slain journalist's body shows signs of torture in Mexico: advocacy group
entry.summary: MEXICO CITY -- Mexican officials said Sunday they are pursuing all lines of investigation into the torture and killing of a photojournalist whose body was found in Mexico City, where he had fled because of harassment in his home state.

entry.title: Mexican photojournalist found dead was likely tortured, activists say
entry.summary:
Espinosa was found dead late on Friday in an apartment in Mexico City.

Espinosa's killing has raised tension among reporters who long have considered Mexico's capital to be a refuge from media intimidation and violence elsewhere in Mexico.

entry.title: Journalist slain in Mexico City had signs of torture
Run-in with reporter triggered Mexico coach Herrera's ouster
Run-in with reporter triggered Mexico coach Herrera's ouster
entry.summary: "El Piojo" is the latest to depart from what has become a revolving-door job since Ricardo La Volpe of Argentina was the last to complete a four-year World Cup cycle as Mexico's head coach.

entry.title: Run-in with reporter triggered Mexico coach Herrera's ouster
entry.summary: MEXICO CITY (AP) - In the end it wasn't the middling on-field performance by Mexico's national soccer team that cost Miguel Herrera his job as head coach of "El Tri."

entry.title: Mexico border state hails 'historic' sentencing of 5 men to 697 years for killings of 11 women
Mexico border state hails 'historic' sentencing of 5 men to 697 years for killings of 11 women
entry.summary: MEXICO CITY - Mexican prosecutors announced Tuesday that they had won "historic" convictions and sentences of 697 years in prison against five men for killing 11 women near the border city of Ciudad Juarez.

entry.title: Mexico to clean seaweed from coast, monitor floating masses
Mexico coach Herrera fired after claim he punched reporter
entry.summary: Mexico has burned through 10 head coaches in the nine years since La Volpe departed after the 2006 World Cup in Germany.

entry.title: Mexico coach Herrera fired after claim he punched reporter
entry.summary:
During his tenure Mexico won 18 matches, tied 11 and lost 7.

Earlier this year he and two players came under investigation by the soccer federation for tweets supporting Mexico's Green Party just before midterm elections, an apparent violation of the federation's code of ethics.

entry.title: Future unsure for troubled New Mexico green chile production
entry.summary:
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (AP) - Green chiles have defined New Mexico for generations, gaining fans and fame around the globe.

"The labor force is getting older and not a lot of young people are getting into the business," said Ed Ogaz, owner of the Anthony, New Mexico-based chile wholesaler Seco Spice Co. "Something needs to happen."

Chile has been a staple of New Mexico cuisine for centuries, and the Hatch region has become world famous for its flavorful hot peppers.

Experts say the state is losing chile acreage to West Texas and Mexico, partly because of the cost and availability of labor.

They point to New Mexico Chile Association numbers that say the full economic impact of chiles, both fresh and processed, was more than $460 million a year.

entry.title: Future unsure for troubled New Mexico green chile production
entry.summary: Green chiles, the signature crop of New Mexico, are in danger.

entry.title: Mexico coach Herrera fired after claim he punched reporter
entry.summary: De Maria did not announce a replacement for Herrera, who led Mexico to the round of 16 at last year's World Cup.

entry.title: Embattled Mexico soccer coach 'El Piojo' Herrera fired after claim he punched journalist
entry.summary: MEXICO CITY - Embattled Mexican national soccer team coach Miguel Herrera has been fired following a TV reporter's claim that the coach known as "El Piojo" punched him.

entry.title: Mexico national soccer coach fired after journalist's claim
entry.summary: Mexico advanced to the final after winning two knockout-round matches with the help of controversial late penalties.

entry.title: Embattled Mexico soccer coach 'El Piojo' Herrera fired after claim he punched journalist
Mexico national soccer coach fired after journalist's claim
New machines aim to revive troubled New Mexico green chile
entry.summary: Efforts are underway to save the green chile that's important to traditional New Mexican fare as labor shortages, a previous severe drought and competition from China, India and Mexico endanger its growth in the state.

entry.title: New machines aim to revive troubled New Mexico green chile
entry.summary: New Mexico land dedicated to growing chile has long been declining, and experts say mechanization might stop or even reverse the trend.

entry.title: New machines aim to revive troubled New Mexico green chile
entry.summary: Federal numbers show overall chile acreage harvested across New Mexico fell last year to a 43-year low.

entry.title: Mexico struggles to clean seaweed surge from Cancun beaches
entry.summary:
Authorities on Mexico's Caribbean coast said Monday they are redoubling efforts to remove tons of sargassum seaweed that has been washing ashore in recent weeks.

Officials in the Caribbean island of Barbados have also struggled with seaweed washing ashore, and large piles of sargassum washed up on the shore in Galveston, Texas, in 2014 after drifting into the Gulf of Mexico.

entry.title: Mexico finds cocaine diluted in fruit shipment from Colombia
Mexico finds cocaine diluted in fruit shipment from Colombia
entry.summary:
Customs and law enforcement personnel in Mexico say they found an undetermined amount of cocaine dissolved in fruit pulp imported from Colombia.

Mexico's customs and tax authority said Monday that it was a "sophisticated" and "unprecedented" smuggling attempt.

entry.title: Mexico national team coach allegedly hits TV journalist
Mexico national team coach allegedly hits TV journalist
entry.summary: The coach of Mexico's national soccer team is known for his histrionic displays of emotion during games.

entry.title: Mexico wins 7th Gold Cup title with 3-1 victory over Jamaica
entry.summary:
Mexico's Andres Guardado, (18) celebrates his goal with teammates during the first half of the CONCACAF Gold Cup championship soccer match against Jamaica, Sunday, July 26, 2015, in Philadelphia.

Mexico ensured the final wouldn't come down to any calls in the final minutes with a 3-1 victory over upstart Jamaica for the CONCACAF Gold Cup title Sunday.

entry.title: El Tri grab seventh CONCACAF Gold Cup title
entry.summary: Jamaica hadn't trailed since early in the second half of its Gold Cup opener before a yellow card helped lead to Mexico's first goal.

entry.title: Mexico wins 7th Gold Cup title with victory over Jamaica
entry.summary: Another mistake by Hector in the 61st minute put Mexico up 3-0.

entry.title: Mexico's search for 43 missing students turns up 60 clandestine graves
entry.summary: On Sunday, a few hundred people led by parents of the missing youths marched in Mexico City to call for justice in the case.

entry.title: Mexico search for missing students turns up 129 bodies
entry.summary:
The search for 43 missing college students in the southern state of Guerrero has turned up at least 60 clandestine graves and 129 bodies over the last 10 months, Mexico's attorney general's office says.

More than 20,000 people are listed as missing across Mexico, and there are many "disappeared" in Guerrero, a state that is a major opium producer and the battleground among several cartels warring over territory and drug smuggling routes.

entry.title: Mexico police bust greenhouses with genetically modified pot
Mexico's federal police arrest 25 at greenhouses growing genetically modified marijuana
entry.summary:
MEXICO CITY - Federal authorities in Mexico say they arrested 22 Colombians and three Mexicans using greenhouses to grow genetically modified and cloned marijuana.

The statement says the Colombians said they had been contacted by emails offering them jobs in the Mexico and they ended up at the site in the municipality of Tlajomulco de Zunia.

entry.title: Mexico's search for 43 missing students has turned up 60 clandestine graves with 129 bodies
Mexico search for missing students turns up 129 bodies
Rolling Jamaica, reeling Mexico meet in Gold Cup final
entry.summary:
PHILADELPHIA (AP) " Mexico is the favorite to win its record-extending seventh CONCACAF Gold Cup title, and coach Miguel Herrera is answering questions about his future with the team.

Indeed, Mexico did outplay Costa Rica in the quarterfinals, though that game was moments from going to penalty kicks until El Tri benefited from another questionable call in the last minute of extra time.

The only way Mexico has been able to score during the knockout rounds is on penalty kicks.

entry.title: Lightning strike kills 7, including 4 children, in central Mexico
entry.summary: MEXICO CITY - Authorities say a lightning strike has killed seven people, including four children, in a rural part of central Mexico.

entry.title: At Mexico's narco cemetery, palatial tombs await the inevitable end for gang members

entry.title: Mexico rights group: Errors, omissions in case of 43 missing
entry.summary: MEXICO CITY (AP) " Mexico's human rights commission says the government's investigation into the fate of 43 missing college students is marked by failures and omissions in its procedures.

entry.title: At Mexico's narco cemetery, graves await the inevitable
entry.summary:
CULIACAN, Mexico (AP) " Palatial tombs mark the final resting spots of top narcotics traffickers in the Jardines de Humaya cemetery in the Sinaloa state capital of Culiacan.

But his escape doesn't seem to have sparked additional violence in this area, apparently with few new burials here in the nearly two weeks since he slipped out of Mexico's highest-security prison.

entry.title: New Mexico police chief wants fugitive in Cuba returned for 1971 officer's death
entry.summary:
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. - The New Mexico State Police chief says he would personally pay for a return ticket for a fugitive living in Cuba wanted in the killing of a New Mexico police officer.

Hill fled to the communist island after authorities say he killed state police officer Robert Rosenbloom in New Mexico in 1971.

Responding to President Barack Obama's move to thaw relations with Cuba, New Mexico Gov. Susana Martinez in December renewed a request that the Obama administration try to extradite Hill, who is now 65 years old.

entry.title: New Mexico Democratic lawmaker to stay on LULAC board
entry.summary: A New Mexico Democratic lawmaker says she will not resign from the board of the nation's oldest Latino civil rights group despite calls to step down.

entry.title: US ponders a shocking loss; Mexico advances with ugly win
entry.summary:
That will go to either Mexico or Jamaica, who meet in Sunday's final at Philadelphia.

Mexico won it after Geiger awarded another kick for Harold Cummings' takedown of Javier Orozco in the penalty area, setting up Guardado's winning goal in the 105th.

entry.title: Guardado lifts Mexico past angry Panama, 2-1, in Gold Cup
entry.summary:
Panama played at a disadvantage after forward Luis Tejada drew a red card and was ejected for his contact with Mexico's Francisco Rodriguez about 25 minutes into the match.

Similar controversy surrounded Mexico's 1-0 win over Costa Rica in the quarterfinals Sunday night.

entry.title: Jamaica stuns U.S. men?s team, faces Mexico for Gold Cup title
entry.summary: Mexico 2, Panama 1: Andres Guardado scored two goals on penalty kicks, including the tiebreaker in extra time, and Mexico beat shorthanded and angered Panama.

entry.title: Donald Trump to visit US-Mexico border
entry.summary: NEWARK, NJ - Donald Trump, provocateur of the Republican presidential race, now plans to go the Mexican border, a flashpoint in the primary contest ever since he declared that immigrants from Mexico are rapists and drug dealers.

entry.title: Donald Trump will visit Mexico-Texas border Thursday
After escape, Mexico's strongest cartel boss faces radically altered drug-trafficking business
entry.summary:
MEXICO CITY - Mexico's most powerful drug lord, Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman, has a lot to catch up on as he returns to a drug-trafficking landscape that has shifted considerably during his 17 months behind bars.

Only the Jalisco New Generation, the big gun cartel that forced down the helicopter, has used the void to grow into one of Mexico's most powerful international criminal groups.

"The Jalisco cartel has been growing ... and Sinaloa was debilitated by the arrest of El Chapo," said Raul Benitez, a security expert with the National Autonomous University of Mexico.

entry.title: AP Exclusive: 'Breaking Bad' actor runs for Albuquerque seat
entry.summary: But Quezada said the state party needed to go more to reach out to Latino voters, especially since New Mexico has the highest percentage of Hispanic residents in the county.

entry.title: AP Exclusive: 'Breaking Bad' actor runs for Albuquerque seat
entry.summary: Citing sprawl development and a need for more Mexican-American elected officials, "Breaking Bad" actor Steven Michael Quezada said he is jumping in a heated race for county commissioner in Albuquerque, New Mexico.

entry.title: Mexico tops Costa Rica 1-0 in Gold Cup on late penalty
entry.summary: "We shouldn't take away from Mexico," he said.

entry.title: Mexico tops Costa Rica 1-0 in Gold Cup on late penalty
entry.summary: The Mexico-Costa Rica matchup looked like a potential final at the start of the tournament, with Costa Rica coming off a World Cup quarterfinal appearance last year.

entry.title: Mexico tops Costa Rica 1-0 in Gold Cup on late penalty
entry.summary:
Mexico won 1-0 on Sunday night in the CONCACAF Gold Cup quarterfinals on Andres Guardado's penalty kick in the final minute of extra time.

Angry Costa Rica fans - heavily outnumbered by Mexico's supporters in the crowd of 74,187 at MetLife Stadium - threw bottles toward the field in protest.

entry.title: Panama, Mexico in CONCACAF Gold Cup semis
entry.summary: Guardado converted to send six-time champion Mexico to the semifinals, in which it will face Panama on Wednesday night in Atlanta.

entry.title: Mexico City cabbies slam regulations on ride-sharing apps
entry.summary: Representatives of Mexico City's regular cab drivers are criticizing new regulations published this week on ride-sharing apps such as Uber.

entry.title: Mexico attorney general says US drug lord's extradition before escape
entry.summary: MEXICO CITY - Mexico's government is confirming that the United States filed an extradition request for drug lord Joaquin Guzman about 2 weeks before he escaped from Mexico's highest-security prison.

entry.title: Uber praises new Mexico City regulations allowing smartphone-based ride-sharing services
entry.summary: MEXICO CITY - The Uber ride-sharing app praised Mexico City's decision to become the first city in Latin America - and the largest in the world - to issue official regulations for such smartphone-based services.

entry.title: Uber praises new Mexico City regulations; cabbies grouse
entry.summary: Uber's spokesman for Mexico and Central America says the company doesn't mind paying 1.5 percent of the proceeds from each ride into a transport-improvement fund.

entry.title: Ranchers sue over rule giving feds authority on state water
entry.summary: Ranchers in New Mexico, California and Washington state are challenging a new Obama administration rule giving federal agencies authority to protect some streams and wetlands.

entry.title: Mexico draws in frenetic finish, gets Costa Rica in quarterfinal
entry.summary: Trinidad and Tobago (2-0-1, 7 points) took Group C's top seed into the quarterfinals, and will face Panama on Sunday in East Rutherford, N.J. Mexico (1-0-2, 5 points) will play Costa Rica in the second game Sunday.

entry.title: Mexico, Trinidad and Tobago draw in Gold Cup
entry.summary: "We had an objective to get to the quarterfinals. We wanted to win the first game and get the result from Cuba (a 2-0 win on July 12), and not have to play Mexico to get to the quarterfinals."

entry.title: Mexico, Trinidad and Tobago draw in Gold Cup
entry.summary:
Two goals in stoppage time led to a 4-4 draw between Mexico and Trinidad and Tobago on Wednesday night in their final group match at the CONCACAF Gold Cup.

Tied 3-3 through regulation, Mexico pulled ahead on an own goal by Trinidad and Tobago defender Cordell Cato in the first minute of extra play.

Mexico (1-0-2, 5 points) will play Costa Rica in the second quarterfinal game Sunday.

entry.title: Mexico distributes photos, erects checkpoints in search for escaped drug lord
Mexico searches nationwide for escaped drug lord
Mexico City publishes regulations allowing Uber and other smartphone-based ride-sharing apps
entry.summary:
MEXICO CITY - Mexico City has published new regulations that will allow Uber and other smartphone-based ride-sharing apps to operate over the objections of taxi drivers.

In a statement, Uber commended the regulations issued Wednesday and said Mexico City was the largest in the world to take such a step.

entry.title: Mexico opens oil sector to private companies with first auction, but draws few bids
entry.summary:
MEXICO CITY - Mexico is getting off to a rough start in its effort to attract investment for its oil fields by allowing private companies to enter the energy sector after a seven-decade state monopoly.

Only two of 14 exploration and production blocks in the Gulf of Mexico put up for auction Wednesday attracted bids, and the auction did not attract the world's biggest oil companies.

Until last year's legislative overhaul, Mexico's oil sector had been closed to private companies since nationalization in 1938.

entry.title: Mexico drug lord escape tunnel is audacious engineering feat
entry.summary: Mexico's most prized prisoner paced his cell, first to the latrine, then the shower, then the bed.

entry.title: Hurricane Dolores strengthens to Category 4 storm in Pacific
entry.summary: Swells generated by the hurricane are affecting parts of Mexico's southwestern coast along with the southern coast of the Baja California peninsula.

entry.title: Hurricane Dolores strengthens to Category 4 storm in Pacific
entry.summary: Hurricane Dolores has rapidly strengthened to a powerful Category 4 storm in the Pacific off Mexico's coast.

entry.title: Mexico drug lord escape tunnel is audacious engineering feat
entry.summary: Eduardo Castillo reported from Mexico City.

entry.title: Mexico drug lord escape tunnel is audacious engineering feat
entry.summary: Seven more strides and the man who Mexico's government said could not possibly repeat his 2001 prison escape stepped through a sliding steel door into the chilly night on a high plain west of the capital.

entry.title: Mexico launches nationwide search for escaped drug lord 'El Chapo' Guzman
entry.summary: Mexico's government on Tuesday broadcast security camera footage of Guzman in the final moments before he escaped from the maximum security prison.

entry.title: Dos Santos to return for Mexico in Gold Cup
entry.summary: CHARLOTTE, North Carolina (Reuters) - Mexico will recall the barely used Giovani Dos Santos for their key Gold Cup match against Trinidad and Tobago, coach Miguel Herrera said on Tuesday.

entry.title: Mexico offers $5.1 million for ?El Chapo?
entry.summary: Fugitive ... A poster with the face of Mexican drug lord Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman, reading "Wanted, Again", is displayed at a newsstand in one Mexico City's major bus terminals.
